hints.content:
The absolute minimum point of a graph is the point that is lower than *all* other points on the graph.

Note that this is different from a *relative* minimum point, which is lower than all other points *around it* but not necessarily lower than all points on the graph.

For instance, this graph has relative minimum points at $(-4,0)$, $(2,-1)$, and $(7,-3)$, but only one of them is the absolute minimum point.

The graph's absolute minimum point is $(7,-3)$.



[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by one. A function is made up of line segments and curved lines. The function starts at negative seven, three and decreases at a non linear rate to negative four, zero. Then it increases at a non linear rate to zero, seven. Then the function decreases at a nonlinear rate to two, negative one. Then it increases at a non linear rate to three, three. A line segment connects three, three, to seven, negative three.

The absolute maximum point of a graph is the point that is higher than *all* other points on the graph.

Note that this is different from a *relative* maximum point, which is higher than all other points *around it* but not necessarily higher than all points on the graph.

For instance, this graph has relative maximum points at $(-6,3)$, $(-1,7)$, and $(2,3)$, but only one of them is the absolute maximum point.

The graph's absolute maximum point is $(-1,7)$.
